speaker: James
text: The Yulia story, from our piece on a 'Lost Generation,' is truly jarring. A talented engineer, forced into prostitution in 1996 Moscow. You remember it?

speaker: Elena
text: Vividly. It's a stark image. But James, that was post-Soviet collapse. Utter chaos. Are you really suggesting we're in a comparable situation today?

speaker: James
text: Not identical, no. But the parallels with Western youth unemployment and precarity are becoming alarmingly close. That's the argument, isn't it?

speaker: Elena
text: Alarmingly close? I think you're cherry-picking. A recession is not societal collapse.

speaker: James
text: Tell that to the 61% of young people unemployed in Greece, or 51% in Spain, back in 2013. Or the 20% in the UK then.

speaker: Elena
text: Those are terrible numbers, I agree. But many found work elsewhere. London is full of them. They're not on the streets.

speaker: James
text: As waiters and nannies, often with university degrees. Is that the promise we made them? 'Upwardly mobile professionals'?

speaker: Elena
text: It's a temporary step. A difficult one, yes, but they're resilient. They'll find their way.

speaker: James
text: Will they? When house prices have soared beyond reach? When a deposit is a family handout, not earned savings?

speaker: Elena
text: That's a systemic problem, not a sign of imminent collapse. We need different housing policies, clearly.

speaker: James
text: It has consequences. People delay marriage. They delay children. The article notes the Russian fertility rate plummeted to 1.17 by 1999.

speaker: Elena
text: Hold on— that's extreme. We're not seeing that here. People are just having kids later, or perhaps fewer.

speaker: James
text: Fewer, precisely. Our fertility rates are well below replacement. The demographic 'kite' rather than the 'pyramid' we discussed in 'Crisis: Origins of the Decline of the West'.

speaker: Elena
text: Okay, the demographic shift is real. I'll give you that. But it's not Yulia's story.

speaker: James
text: Not yet. But the article's point is that a generation faces truncated dreams. The 'Downton Abbey' scenario, where the rich have 'home help'—

speaker: Elena
text: Oh, come on. We're not going back to upstairs-downstairs. Automation is taking those jobs anyway. See our piece on renewables and battery tech.

speaker: James
text: Precisely. Capital buys robots, siphons off service jobs. If you don't assist the robots, you're competing with them. Your wages drop.

speaker: Elena
text: So, the educated young are left with no decent work, no housing, no family future. What are governments doing?

speaker: James
text: Sleepwalking, largely. Hoping for 'a little bit of growth' to fix it. Denial, as the article puts it.

speaker: Elena
text: That's unfair. They're trying to stimulate the economy, invest in green tech—

speaker: James
text: But structural problems require structural solutions. And those take time, far longer than an electoral cycle. Politicians don't have that luxury.

speaker: Elena
text: So, what are the 'tempting solutions' the article mentions? I dread to ask.

speaker: James
text: Mass immigration, for one. Young taxpayers to fund the pensions. Turn the kite back into a pyramid.

speaker: Elena
text: That's already happening. And it does help. New blood, new energy.

speaker: James
text: But if there are no jobs for the *indigenous* young, what happens when immigrants arrive and find none either? The problem is compounded, not solved.

speaker: Elena
text: They integrate eventually. Contribute. It's not a zero-sum game.

speaker: James
text: The article suggests another 'solution': suppressing young voters. Making property ownership a requirement.

speaker: Elena
text: No. That's completely wrong, and I'll tell you why. That's not a solution, that's outright disenfranchisement. Anti-democratic.

speaker: James
text: I agree it's abhorrent. But the article points out the US already uses similar tactics. Lock up minorities for petty crimes, they lose the vote.

speaker: Elena
text: That's not a model to emulate, James. That's a moral failing, a perversion of democracy, not a fix for economic woes.

speaker: James
text: It shows the desperation politicians might descend to. To shore up the older, wealthier, property-owning voters. To protect their pensions.

speaker: Elena
text: But it won't fix the underlying economic crisis. It just silences the people most affected. That's not a solution, it's a cover-up.

speaker: James
text: Indeed. The article concludes by recalling the Soviet collapse. Unexpected, yet in hindsight, predictable. We have so many structural problems today, it requires little imagination to forecast similar decline. 'The Rise of the West Was Based on Luck' comes to mind.

speaker: Elena
text: Are you really saying we're headed for collapse? Like Rome, or the Ottomans?

speaker: James
text: Broken systems can survive for centuries. But the Yulia story... and the article's closing question about our own daughters...

speaker: Elena
text: What choices will they have to make? Well... okay, that's harder to argue with than I expected.

speaker: James
text: The feeling of dread is intentional. The question is, how long can we ignore it before the choices become truly grim?

speaker: Elena
text: Before 'temporary' unemployment becomes structural, before delayed families become no families. Before 'difficult choices' become impossible ones.
